title: Dwayne R. Tucker, MSc, PhD Candidate
text:
Email
  
  
    
     GitHub
  
  
    
     Twitter-X
  
  
    
     Google Scholar
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     CV
  

  
  


Hi!
I am a PhD candidate at  The University of British Columbia (UBC)  in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. As part of the  Endometriosis & Pelvic Pain Laboratory  and  Uterine Health Reasearch Lab , my doctoral research delves into predicting pain outcomes in endometriosis, employing a combination of machine learning, clinical modelling, and molecular pathology approaches.
I am a trained clinical laboratory scientist with extensive experience in chemical pathology and haematology, gained at  The University of the West Indies  and the  University Hospital of the West Indies , in Jamaica.
Through my professional and doctoral work, I developed a keen interest in leveraging the power of data to advance health outcomes, particularly amongst marginalized communities.




Data Science (Predictive Modelling & Machine Learning)
Research Methods
Health Outcomes & Epidemiology
Science Communication & Medical Writing

title: Dwayne R. Tucker, MSc, PhD Candidate
text:
Data Science (Predictive Modelling & Machine Learning)
Research Methods
Health Outcomes & Epidemiology
Science Communication & Medical Writing

title: Academic Projects
text: This ongoing project aims to develop a prediction model to estimate a patient’s risk of unfavorable pain outcomes after endometriosis surgery, before the surgery is performed. The goal is to facilitate the decision-making discussion between patients and clinicians. For this work, I am employing machine learning algorithms, including the exploration of neural networks, to model the complex relationship between preoperative factors in endometriosis patients and their pain outcomes. The model will be presented using the R shiny platform and will be made available once published. The project utilizes prospectively collected clinical data from the Endometriosis Pelvic Pain Interdisciplinary Cohort (EPPIC).

title: Research
text:
Tucker DR, Noga HL, Lee C, Chiu DS, Bedaiwy MA, Williams C, Allaire C, Talhouk A, Yong PJ. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2023;229(2):147.e1-147.e20.  

Endometriosis is a chronic condition affecting ~10% of reproductive-aged women. Surgery is an effective treatment for most individuals experiencing endometriosis-related pain, however a significant proportion experience persistent/ recurrent pain. Persistent/ recurrent pain after endometriosis surgery may be due to central sensitization or nociplastic pain. In centralized pain, pain processing in the brain is altered leading to pain perception even after the pain stimili (e.g. endometriosis lesions) is removed. In this prospective longitudinal study, we examined whether the preoperative presence of pelvic pain comorbidities, indicative of underlying central sensitization,is associated with worse pain-related quality of life after endometriosis surgery.
 
 






 Zoet G, Tucker DR, Orr NL, Alotaibi FT, Liu YD, Noga H, Köbel M, Yong PJ.Front Reprod Health. 2023;5:1297986.  

We propose a standardized protocol for the measurement of nerve bundle density (PGP9.5) in endometriosis environment (including deep endometriosis, ovarian endometriomas and superficial peritoneal endometriosis) as a potential biomarker reflecting local neurogenesis.
 
 
 
 
 






 Tucker D, Zheng W, Zhang DH, Dong X. World J Clin Oncol. 2020;11(8):563-572.  

Advancing knowledge of the transcriptome has revealed that circular RNAs (circRNAs) are widely expressed and evolutionarily conserved molecules that may serve relevant biological roles. More interesting is the accumulating evidence which demonstrates the implication of circRNAs in diseases, especially cancers. This revelation has helped to form the rationale for many studies exploring their utility as clinical biomarkers. CircRNAs are highly stable due to their unique structures, exhibit some tissue specificity, and are enriched in exosomes, which facilitate their detection in a range of body fluids. These properties make circRNAs ideal candidates for biomarker development in many diseases. This review will outline the discovery, biogenesis, and proposed functions of circRNAs.

title: Academic Projects
text:
Journal Reviews

Assessing the Utility of artificial intelligence in endometriosis: Promises and pitfalls
 Dungate B, Tucker DR, Goodwin E, Yong PJ. Womens Health (Lond). 2024;20:17455057241248121.  

This study examines how artificial intelligence (AI) can improve the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis, a condition that affects many women but is underfunded and hard to diagnose due to varied symptoms. AI, which analyzes large datasets to find new patterns, is increasingly used in medical research. Its applications in endometriosis include diagnostic tools and treatment prediction, potentially reducing diagnostic delays, healthcare costs, and providing better treatment options. However, AI’s success depends on high-quality data and skilled implementation. The review highlights the need for careful and transparent use of AI to avoid mistakes and ensure reliable outcomes, calling for more oversight in AI research to enhance endometriosis care.
 


Circular RNA and its potential as prostate cancer biomarkers
 Tucker D, Zheng W, Zhang DH, Dong X. World J Clin Oncol. 2020;11(8):563-572.  

Advancing knowledge of the transcriptome has revealed that circular RNAs (circRNAs) are widely expressed and evolutionarily conserved molecules that may serve relevant biological roles. More interesting is the accumulating evidence which demonstrates the implication of circRNAs in diseases, especially cancers. This revelation has helped to form the rationale for many studies exploring their utility as clinical biomarkers. CircRNAs are highly stable due to their unique structures, exhibit some tissue specificity, and are enriched in exosomes, which facilitate their detection in a range of body fluids. These properties make circRNAs ideal candidates for biomarker development in many diseases. This review will outline the discovery, biogenesis, and proposed functions of circRNAs.

title: check
text:
```ljexxthmhdqlo #| standalone: true
library(timevis) library(shiny)
data <- data.frame( id = 1:4, content = c(“Item one”, “Item two”, “Ranged item”, “Item four”), start = c(“2016-01-10”, “2016-01-11”, “2016-01-20”, “2016-02-14 15:00:00”), end = c(NA, NA, “2016-02-04”, NA) )
ui <- fluidPage( timevisOutput(“timeline”) )
server <- function(input, output, session) { output$timeline <- renderTimevis({ timevis(data) }) }
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

title: check
text:
```znixvjiizlxkd #| standalone: true
library(timevis) library(shiny)
data2 <- data.frame( id = 1:4, content = c(“Item one”, “Item two”, “Ranged item”, “Item four”), start = c(“2016-01-10”, “2016-01-11”, “2016-01-20”, “2016-02-14 15:00:00”), end = c(NA, NA, “2016-02-04”, NA) )
ui <- fluidPage( timevisOutput(“timeline”) )
server <- function(input, output, session) { output$timeline <- renderTimevis({ timevis(data2) }) }
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
